Isaac Newton: Newton's work in mathematics and physics revolutionized the scientific world and laid the foundation for modern physics. His insights into the laws of motion and gravity have had a profound impact on our understanding of the universe and have shaped the technological advancements of the past few centuries.

Leonardo da Vinci: Leonardo da Vinci was a true polymath, excelling in multiple fields such as art, science, engineering, and philosophy. His contributions to the fields of anatomy, botany, and flight, among others, would provide valuable insights into the history of science and technology.

Marie Curie: Marie Curie's groundbreaking work in radioactivity and nuclear physics earned her two Nobel Prizes and made her the first woman to receive the award. Her dedication to science and her determination to succeed in a male-dominated field would serve as an inspiration to future generations of female scientists.

Shakespeare: Shakespeare's works have had an enduring impact on literature and culture, and his ability to capture the human condition remains unparalleled. Bringing him back to life would provide an opportunity to learn more about his life, his writing process, and the context in which he lived.

Mahatma Gandhi: Gandhi's non-violent approach to social change and his commitment to achieving independence for India through civil disobedience have made him a hero and an inspiration to people around the world. His wisdom and his ability to lead by example would be invaluable in today's complex and often divisive world.
